S2.T1.caption: Table 1: The number of parameters, maximal rank, and example. We assume that the weights of the FC and convolutional layers are in ℝm×nsuperscriptℝ𝑚𝑛\mathbb{R}^{m\times n} and ℝO×I×K1×K2superscriptℝ𝑂𝐼subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2\mathbb{R}^{O\times I\times K_{1}\times K_{2}}, respectively. The rank of the convolutional layer is the rank of the 1stsuperscript1st1^{\mathrm{st}} unfolding tensor. As a reference example, we set m=n=O=I=256,K1=K2=3formulae-sequence𝑚𝑛𝑂𝐼256subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾23m=n=O=I=256,K_{1}=K_{2}=3, and R=16𝑅16R=16.
references:
Equation 3 implies the criteria that minimize the number of weight parameters used in our parameterization with the target rank constraint of the constructed matrix as R2superscript𝑅2R^{2}.
Proposition 2 provides an efficient way to set the hyper-parameters.
It implies that, if we set r1=r2=Rsubscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2𝑅r_{1}{=}r_{2}{=}R and R2≥min⁡(m,n)superscript𝑅2𝑚𝑛R^{2}\geq\min(m,n), FedPara is highly likely to have no low-rank restriction222Its corollary and empirical evidence can be found in the supplementary material. Under Proposition 2, R2≥min⁡(m,n)superscript𝑅2𝑚𝑛R^{2}\geq\min(m,n) is a necessary and sufficient condition for achieving a maximal rank. even with much fewer parameters than that of a naïve weight, i.e., 2​R​(m+n)≪m​nmuch-less-than2𝑅𝑚𝑛𝑚𝑛2R(m+n)\ll mn.
Moreover, given the same number of parameters, rank​(𝐖)rank𝐖\mathrm{rank}(\mathbf{W}) of FedPara is higher than that of the naïve low-rank parameterization by a square factor, as shown in Figure 1 and Table 1.

Proposition 3 is the extension of Proposition 1 but can be applied to the convolutional layer without reshaping.
In the convolutional layer case of Table 1, given the specific tensor size, Proposition 3 requires 3.83.83.8 times fewer parameters than Proposition 1.
Hence, we use Proposition 3 for the convolutional layer since the tensor method is more effective for common convolutional models.

We train VGG16 with PufferFish and FedPara on the CIFAR-10 IID dataset in FL, and evaluate the models according to varying the number of parameters. As shown in Table 10, our FedPara has higher accuracy with fewer parameters compared with PufferFish. Although PufferFish is superior to the naive low-rank pre-decomposition method due to its hybrid architecture, we think the hybrid architecture of PufferFish still suffers from the low-rank constraints on the top layers. However, our method is free from such limitations both theoretically and empirically.

We train LSTMori.subscriptLSTMori\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{ori.}}, LSTMlowsubscriptLSTMlow\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{low}}, and LSTMFedParasubscriptLSTMFedPara\texttt{LSTM}_{\texttt{FedPara}} on the Shakespeare dataset.
The parameters ratio of LSTMlowsubscriptLSTMlow\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{low}} and LSTMFedParasubscriptLSTMFedPara\texttt{LSTM}_{\texttt{FedPara}} are about 16%percent1616\% and 19%percent1919\% of the LSTMori.subscriptLSTMori\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{ori.}} parameters, respectively.
Table 11 shows that LSTMFedParasubscriptLSTMFedPara\texttt{LSTM}_{\texttt{FedPara}} outperforms LSTMlowsubscriptLSTMlow\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{low}} and LSTMori.subscriptLSTMori\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{ori.}} on the IID setting.
In the non-IID setting, LSTMFedParasubscriptLSTMFedPara\texttt{LSTM}_{\texttt{FedPara}} accuracy is higher than LSTMlowsubscriptLSTMlow\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{low}} and slightly lower than LSTMori.subscriptLSTMori\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{ori.}} with only 19%percent1919\% of parameters.
Therefore, our parameterization can be applied to general neural networks.

Table 12 shows the comparison between FedPara and FedPAQ as well as those integration.
Compared to FedPAQ, FedPara transfers 1.96 times lower bits per round because FedPAQ only reduces the uplink communication cost.
Compared with FedAvg, FedPara achieves 0.14%percent\% higher accuracy, but FedPAQ 1.01%percent\% lower accuracy.
FedPara can transfer the full information of updated weights to the server, whereas FedPAQ loses the updated weight information due to the quantization.
Furthermore, since the way FedPara reduces communication costs is different from quantization, we integrate FedPara with FedPAQ as an extension.
Combining our method with FedPAQ reduces communication costs by 25%percent2525\% further from our FedPara without the integration while having a minor accuracy drop, 0.1%percent\%, from that of FedAvg.

In Table 2, we validate the propositions stating that our FedPara achieves a higher rank than the low-rank parameterization given the same number of parameters.
We train VGG16lowsubscriptVGG16low\texttt{VGG16}_{\mathrm{low}} and VGG16FedParasubscriptVGG16FedPara\texttt{VGG16}_{\texttt{FedPara}} for the same target rounds T𝑇T, and use 10.25%percent10.2510.25\% and 10.15%percent10.1510.15\% of the VGG16ori.subscriptVGG16ori\texttt{VGG16}_{\mathrm{ori.}} parameters, respectively, to be comparable.
As shown in Table 2a, VGG16FedParasubscriptVGG16FedPara\texttt{VGG16}_{\texttt{FedPara}} surpasses VGG16lowsubscriptVGG16low\texttt{VGG16}_{\mathrm{low}} on all the IID and non-IID settings benchmarks with noticeable margins.
The same tendency is observed in the recurrent neural networks as shown in Table 2b. We train LSTM on the subset of Shakespeare.
Table 2b shows that LSTMFedParasubscriptLSTMFedPara\texttt{LSTM}_{\texttt{FedPara}} has higher accuracy than LSTMlowsubscriptLSTMlow\texttt{LSTM}_{\mathrm{low}}, where the number of parameters is set to 19%percent1919\% and 16%percent1616\% of LSTM, respectively.
This experiment evidences that our FedPara has a better model expressiveness and accuracy than the low-rank parameterization.

We integrate the FedPara-based model with other FL optimizers to show that our FedPara is compatible with them.
We measure the accuracy during the target rounds and the required rounds to achieve the target accuracy.
Table 3 shows that VGG16FedParasubscriptVGG16FedPara\texttt{VGG16}_{\texttt{FedPara}} combined with the current state-of-the-art method, FedDyn, is the best among other combinations.
Thereby, we can further save the communication costs by combining FedPara with other efficient FL approaches.

FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017) is the most popular algorithm in federated learning.
The server samples S𝑆S number of
clients as a subset in each round, each client of the subset trains the model locally by E𝐸E number of SGD epochs,
and the server aggregates the locally updated models and repeats these processes during the total rounds T𝑇T.
We use FedAvg as a backbone optimization algorithm, and its hyper-parameters of our experiments, such as the initial learning rate η𝜂\eta, local batch size B𝐵B, and learning rate decay τ𝜏\tau, are described in Table 6.

references:
Through the extensive experiments, we show the superior performance improvement obtained by our method, and it appears to be with no extra cost. However, the actual payoff exists in the additional computational cost when re-composing the original structure of 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} from our parameterization during training; thus, our method is slower than the original parameterization and low-rank approaches.
However, the computation time is not a dominant factor in practical FL scenarios as shown in Table 7, but rather the communication cost takes a majority of the total training time.
It is evidenced by the fact that FedPara offers better Pareto efficiency than all compared methods because our method has higher accuracy than low-rank approaches and much less training time than the original one.
In contrast, the computation time might be non-negligible compared to the communication time in distributed learning regimes.
While our method can be applied to distributed learning, the benefits of our method may be diminished there.
Improving both computation and communication efficiency of FedPara in large-scale distributed learning requires further research. It would be a promising future direction.

We compare the elapsed time per round of VGG16ori.subscriptVGG16ori\texttt{VGG16}_{\mathrm{ori.}} and VGG16FedParasubscriptVGG16FedPara\texttt{VGG16}_{\texttt{FedPara}} on different network speeds such as 2, 10, and 50 Mbps.
As shown in Table 7, the communication time is larger than the computation time indicating that the communication is a bottleneck in FL as expected.
Although VGG16FedParasubscriptVGG16FedPara\texttt{VGG16}_{\texttt{FedPara}} takes more computation time than VGG16ori.subscriptVGG16ori\texttt{VGG16}_{\mathrm{ori.}} due to the weight composition time, VGG16FedParasubscriptVGG16FedPara\texttt{VGG16}_{\texttt{FedPara}} decreases the communication time by about ten times and the total time by 4.80 to 9.52 times.
Table 8 shows the total training time to achieve the same accuracy on the CIFAR-10 IID setting.
Although FedPara needs three rounds more than the original parameterization, VGG16FedParasubscriptVGG16FedPara\texttt{VGG16}_{\texttt{FedPara}} requires 4.67 to 9.68 times less training time than VGG16ori.subscriptVGG16ori\texttt{VGG16}_{\mathrm{ori.}} because of communication efficient parameterization.
